choices.text: Penicillamine causes Drug-Induced Pemphigus
Subcorneal Split occurs in Pemphigus Foliaceous
Castleman Disease is the most common cause of Paraneoplastic Pemphigus
Intra Epidermal Intercellular Deposition of IgA is seen in IgA Pemphigus

questions.text: All of the following are correct statements EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Castleman Disease is the most common cause

 

Option C:

 

  • Para Neoplastic Pemphigus (PNP) is most commonly associated with Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma (NHL), not Castleman disease.
  • Paraneoplastic pemphigus is most commonly associated with Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma.
  • Castleman disease can be associated with paraneoplastic pemphigus but is not the most common cause.
  • Envoplakin, Desmo Plakin, and Periplakin are the antigens it is linked to.

 

Other associated diseases include:

 

  • ﻿Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
  • ﻿Waldenstrom's disease
  • ﻿Castleman disease.  

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Penicillamine causes Drug-Induced Pemphigus

 

  • Pemphigus caused by drugs typically develops one year after the drug was first taken. It is more common in individuals with other associated autoimmune conditions.

 

Mnemonic for common drugs causing Drug-induced pemphigus – PCR

 

  • Penicillamine,
  • Captopril,
  • Rifampicin.

 

The commonly implicated drugs include:

 

  • ﻿Penicillamine (most common)
  • ﻿ACE inhibitors (Captopril)
  • ﻿Antibiotics - penicillin’s, cephalosporins, rifampicin
  • ﻿Piroxicam
  • ﻿Phenobarbital

 

Option B: Subcorneal split occurs in Pemphigus foliaceous

 

  • In Pemphigus foliaceous the blisters are formed due to a split at the subcorneal layer.
  • A less severe form of pemphigus vulgaris called pemphigus foliaceus has antibodies against desmoglein-1.
  • Due to the lack of antibodies to Dsg-3 antigens, it exhibits flaccid bullae over skin & sparing of the Mucosal surfaces.
  • Erythema, scales, and crust-covered erosions are the common presentation.
  • The histopathology of Pemphigus foliaceous typically shows subcorneal blisters with acantholysis, which is the separation of keratinocytes due to the presence of autoantibodies against desmoglein 1, a desmosomal protein.

 

 

  • Histopathological image of Pemphigus foliaceous (PF) showing subcorneal cleft.

 

Option D: Intra Epidermal intercellular deposition of IgA is seen in IgA pemphigus

 

  • IgA pemphigus is characterized by lgA antibodies against desmosomal components.
  • IntraEpidermal intercellular deposition of IgA on immunofluorescence is seen in IgA pemphigus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Drugs like penicillamine can cause drug-induced pemphigus and IgA deposition is seen in IgA pemphigus, Castleman disease is not the most common cause of paraneoplastic pemphigus; neoplasms such as lymphomas are more commonly implicated.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 50 Page No 50.1-50.8

questions.text: Nikolsky's sign is seen in all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bullous Pemphigoid

 

Explanation:

 

  • Nikolsky sign is absent in subepidermal blistering disorders, so it’s not seen associated with Bullous Pemphigoid.
  • Nikolsky’s sign: On application of tangential pressure over skin on the border of an intact blister → upper layers of epidermis separate from the lower layers →→ skin peels off → extension of the blister.

    ​​​​​​​    ​​​​​​​    ​​​​​​​    

                        Erosion formed → Nikolsky’s sign.

 

 

  • It is seen in conditions that produce intraepidermal blisters. It is negative in subepidermal bullous conditions like bullous pemphigoid, Dermatitis Herpetiformis and epidermolysis bullosa acquisita.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nikolsky's sign is positive in skin disorders with intraepidermal splitting, such as Pemphigus vulgaris, Pemphigus foliaceus, and Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome, but it is negative in Bullous pemphigoid where the split is subepidermal.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 50 Page No 50.3

Bullous Pemphigoid & Tzanck Smear

questions.text: A 43-year-old lady presented with flaccid blisters on her upper chest and back and mucosal lesions as shown. On examination, the bullae were filled with clear fluid. Histopathology revealed a suprabasal split. What is the diagnosis & what is the most accurate diagnostic test to diagnose this condition respectively?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pemphigus Vulgaris & Direct Immunofluorescence Testing

 

Explanation:

 

  • Flaccid bulla on the skin, oral erosions & suprabasal split on histopathology suggest a diagnosis of mucocutaneous Pemphigus Vulgaris.
  • Direct immunofluorescence test is the most accurate test to diagnose Pemphigus Vulgaris.
  • Clinical features: Oral erosions usually precede skin manifestations.
  • The skin lesions are flaccid blisters with clear fluid on an erythematous base, that rupture to produce painful erosions.
  • These are distributed over the face, scalp, upper chest, back, and neck.

 

Investigations:

 

  • Histopathology: The epidermis splits suprabasally in Pemphigus vulgaris, which causes blisters to form. The epidermis splits suprabasally in Pemphigus vulgaris, which causes blisters to form. The basal layer remains adherent to the basement membrane and gives the resemblance to the row of the tombstones.
  • Below image depicts Row of the tombstone’s appearance on histopathology in Pemphigus vulgaris.

 

 

  • Direct immunofluorescence: Direct Immunofluorescence uses anti-|gG antibodies which detects the anti-Desmoglein IgG antibodies deposited on the Desmosomes. In Pemphigus vulgaris there is Intra Epidermal intercellular deposition of IgG and C3, which gives rise to a characteristic appearance called as Fish net / Chicken wire pattern.
  • The below image shows a characteristic fish-net appearance on direct immunofluorescence, which is diagnostic of pemphigus vulgaris.

 

 

Bullous pemphigoid shows subepidermal involvement with tense blisters.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a patient presenting with Flaccid Blisters and Mucosal lesions and histopathology showing a Suprabasal Split, the diagnosis is Pemphigus Vulgaris, and the most accurate diagnostic test is Direct Immunofluorescence Testing.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 50 Page No 50.4-50.8

choices.text: Multinucleated giant cells are seen in varicella-zoster infections.
Tzanck cells are keratinocytes
Acantholytic cells are seen in Pemphigus vulgaris
It is the most accurate test for Pemphigus vulgaris

questions.text: All of the following are correct about Tzanck smear findings EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is the most accurate test for pemphigus vulgaris

 

Option D.

 

  • Direct Immunofluorescence Microscopy (DIF) is the most accurate test for Pemphigus vulgaris, NOT Tzanck smear.
  • This clinical picture is suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris. The first line investigation is Tzanck smear.
  • It allows us to visualize the histology by collecting material from the floor of a fresh blister that is stained with Giemsa or any Romanowsky stain.
  • Tzanck cells are seen on microscopy.
  • Direct immunofluorescence microscopy (DIF) is the most accurate test.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Multinucleated giant cells on a Tzanck smear are seen in varicella-zoster and herpes simplex infections.

 

  • The Frenchman Tzanck invented the Tzanck smear, a cheap, easy-to-use bedside cytological test that aids in the diagnosis of vesicular, pustular, and bullous diseases, particularly herpes.
  • Several techniques can be used to stain Tzanck smears, but Giemsa stain is the most popular.
  • Haematoxylin and eosin, Wright, methylene blue, Papanicolaou, and toluidine blue are additional stains that are employed.
  • Results in Tzanck Smear:

 

Option B: Tzanck cells / Acantholytic cells are Keratinocytes

 

  • They are seen in vesiculobullous disorders, as a result of acantholysis.
  • The keratinocytes lose their polyhedral shapes and characteristically become round with a hypertrophic nucleus, hazy or absent nucleoli, and an abundance of basophilic cytoplasm.
  • Due to the cytoplasm's propensity to condense at the cell's periphery and create a perinuclear halo, the basophilic staining is more pronounced peripherally on the cell membrane ("mourning edged" cells).

 

Option C:

 

Some important findings on Tzanck smear are as follows:

 

 

Image: Tzanck smear, showing multinucleated giant cells in center

 

 

https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Tzanck_test.png

 

The sensitivity of the Tzanck smear exceeds 80%, and the specificity 90% when the investigators are experienced.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Tzanck smear can show multinucleated giant cells in varicella-zoster infections and acantholytic cells in Pemphigus vulgaris, but it is not the most accurate test for Pemphigus vulgaris; that distinction belongs to direct immunofluorescence.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 3.25, 50.4-50.8

choices.text: Linear IgG and C3 Deposition along the Basement Membrane Zone
IgG and C3 Deposition throughout the Epidermis
Granular IgA Deposition at the tips of Dermal Papillae
IgA Deposition in a Fishnet Pattern

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with flaccid vesicles in oral mucosa and trunk. On examination both the bulla spread sign & Nikolsky sign are positive. What pattern will be observed in Direct Immunofluorescence of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgG and C3 deposition throughout the epidermis

 

Option B.

 

  • The diagnosis for the given clinical vignette is Pemphigus vulgaris.
  • It is characterized by autoantibodies against desmogleins, which are components of desmosomes responsible for cell adhesion in the epidermis.
  • Direct Immunofluorescence (DIF) of skin biopsies in Pemphigus vulgaris typically shows IgG and C3 deposition in a reticular or net-like pattern throughout the epidermis, which corresponds with the intercellular spaces between keratinocytes.
  • This is due to the autoantibodies targeting the desmogleins leading to a loss of cell-cell adhesion, a phenomenon known as acantholysis.

 

The below image shows a characteristic fish-net appearance on direct immunofluorescence, which is diagnostic of pemphigus vulgaris.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Linear IgG and C3 deposition along the basement membrane zone –

 

  • This pattern is indicative of Bullous Pemphigoid, an autoimmune blistering disease that affects the basement membrane zone, which is beneath the epidermis.

 

 

  • Unlike Pemphigus vulgaris, Bullous Pemphigoid does not usually involve the oral mucosa as prominently and tends to present with tense rather than flaccid blisters.

 

Option C. Granular IgA deposition at the tips of dermal papillae –

 

  • This deposition pattern is seen in Dermatitis Herpetiformis, which is associated with celiac disease.

 

 

  • Granular IgA deposition at the tips of dermal papillae in Dermatitis Herpetiformis.
  • It presents with pruritic papules and vesicles, primarily on extensor surfaces, and is NOT typically associated with the Nikolsky sign.

 

Option D. IgA deposition in a fishnet pattern –

 

  • This describes the direct immunofluorescence finding in IgA Pemphigus, which is a rarer form of Pemphigus and presents with pustules rather than the flaccid vesicles seen in Pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pemphigus vulgaris, the direct immunofluorescence pattern shows intercellular IgG and C3 deposition throughout the epidermis.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 50 Page No 50.1-50.8

choices.text: Dermatitis Herpetiformis
Pemphigus Vulgaris
Bullous Pemphigoid
Paraneoplastic Pemphigus

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient presents with remitting and relapsing course of mucocutaneous lesions since past 8 years. On examination there are irregular ulcers in oral cavity & crusts and erosions all over trunk & upper limbs. Skin sample for biopsy was taken and sent to pathology department. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient which you expect to see in the report once the reporting from pathology department is ready?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pemphigus Vulgaris

 

Option B.

 

Pemphigus vulgaris

 

  • It is characterized by painful mucocutaneous ulcers that have a chronic relapsing and remitting course.
  • The presence of irregular ulcers in the oral cavity and crusts and erosions on the trunk and upper limbs, as described, is typical for Pemphigus vulgaris.
  • Histopathologically, Pemphigus vulgaris shows intraepidermal bullae due to acantholysis, which is the loss of cohesion between keratinocytes.

 

 

  • Direct Immunofluorescence would show intercellular deposits of IgG and C3 throughout the epidermis.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Dermatitis Herpetiformis:

 

  • This is an intensely pruritic condition associated with gluten sensitivity and presents with grouped vesicles on extensor surfaces.
  • Histology typically shows micro abscesses at the tips of dermal papillae as shown below

 

 

  • Granular IgA deposits on Direct Immunofluorescence.

 

Option C. Bullous Pemphigoid:

 

  • It tends to occur in older patients and presents with large, tense blisters on normal or erythematous skin, rarely affecting the mucous membranes.
  • Histology shows a subepidermal blister with eosinophils, and Direct Immunofluorescence reveals linear IgG and C3 deposits along the basement membrane zone.

 

Option D. Paraneoplastic Pemphigus:

 

  • This condition is associated with underlying neoplasms and presents with polymorphic skin lesions, including blisters, erosions, and papules.
  • Clinically and histologically, it can resemble Pemphigus vulgaris, but it is differentiated by the presence of an underlying tumor and a more complex immunopathologic profile on Direct Immunofluorescence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Diagnose Pemphigus vulgaris in a patient with a long-standing history of mucocutaneous ulcers and erosions, supported by histopathological findings of acantholysis and immunofluorescence showing intercellular IgG and C3 deposition in the epidermis.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 50.4

choices.text: Subcorneal Acantholytic Blister
Subcorneal Non Acantholytic Blister
Sub Epidermal Acantholytic Blister
Sub Eidermal Non Acantholytic Blister

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of a progressive rash that started on her face and has now spread to her chest and scalp over the last 3 months. She reports that the lesions began as small blisters that broke easily, leaving behind crusted, scaly areas and shallow erosions. She denies any mucosal involvement or recent illnesses. She is otherwise healthy and takes no regular medications. On physical examination, you note several superficial erosions with crusts on the scalp and chest. There are no intact blisters, and no lesions are found in the oral cavity. A skin biopsy is taken from the edge of an eroded lesion on the chest. Based on the clinical presentation, what will most likely be observed in the histopathology of the skin biopsy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Subcorneal Acantholytic Blister

 

Option A.

 

Pemphigus Foliaceus (PF)

 

  • The patient's presentation is suggestive of Pemphigus foliaceus, which is a less severe variant of Pemphigus that typically affects the skin but spares the mucosa.
  • It is characterized by superficial blisters that rupture easily, leading to scaly, crusted lesions as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • The histopathology of Pemphigus foliaceus typically shows subcorneal blisters with acantholysis, which is the separation of keratinocytes due to the presence of autoantibodies against desmoglein 1, a desmosomal protein.

 

 

  • Histopathological image of Pemphigus foliaceus (PF) showing subcorneal cleft.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Subcorneal non-acantholytic blister –

 

  • This would suggest a blistering process without cell-cell detachment, which is not consistent with Pemphigus foliaceus.

 

Option C. Subepidermal acantholytic blister –

 

  • This describes a blister beneath the entire epidermis with cell-cell detachment, which is not characteristic of Pemphigus foliaceus.

 

Option D. Subepidermal non-acantholytic blister –

 

  • This would suggest a blister beneath the epidermis without acantholysis, which is seen in conditions like Bullous pemphigoid, not Pemphigus foliaceus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pemphigus foliaceus in patients presenting with superficial, crusted, scaly lesions and shallow erosions on the skin, with histopathology revealing subcorneal acantholytic blisters.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 50.5

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 500

choices.text: BPAG 180
BPAG 230
Desmoglein 1
Desmoglein 3

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented with recurrent episodes of non-healing oral ulcers, bullous eruptions, denuded skin all over body. Which of the following is the most likely antigen causative for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Desmoglein 3.

 

Option D.

 

PEMPHIGUS VULGARIS:

 

  • In pemphigus vulgaris, Desmoglein 3 is the target antigen that is most commonly associated with non-healing oral ulcers and skin blisters.

 

 

  • Desmoglein 1 is also involved, particularly in pemphigus foliaceus which usually presents with skin lesions but sparing the mucosa.

 

 

  • BPAG1 (Bullous Pemphigoid Antigen 1, also known as BPAG 230) and BPAG2 (Bullous Pemphigoid Antigen 2, also known as BPAG 180) are associated with bullous pemphigoid, which typically presents with tense blisters and negative Nikolsky sign, not the denuded skin seen in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. BPAG 180

 

  • Incorrect, associated with bullous pemphigoid, not pemphigus.

 

Option B. BPAG 230

 

  • Incorrect, associated with bullous pemphigoid, not pemphigus.

 

Option C. Desmoglein 1

 

  • Incorrect for this presentation, more often implicated in skin involvement without mucosal lesions.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Desmoglein 3 is the target antigen in pemphigus vulgaris, which presents with non-healing oral ulcers and flaccid blisters over skin.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 50.2

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 498

Pemphigus Vulgaris (PV)

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents with persistent oral lesions that are characterized by ill-defined, irregular margins with peripheral extension and shedding of epithelium as shown in the image below. The lesions are painful and have been recurrent. Histopathological examination reveals suprabasal acantholysis without signs of epidermal necrosis or significant inflammatory infiltrate. The direct immunofluorescence shows intercellular deposits of IgG and C3 in the epidermis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pemphigus Vulgaris (PV).

 

Option B.

 

  • The histopathological finding of suprabasal acantholysis and direct immunofluorescence showing intercellular deposits of IgG and C3 in the epidermis are characteristic of PV, an autoimmune blistering disorder.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Erythema Multiforme (EMF)

 

  • Ittypically presents with target lesions, not suprabasal acantholysis on histopathology.

 

Option C. Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN)

 

  • Itis characterized by widespread epidermal necrosis and detachment.

 

Option D. Herpetic Gingivostomatitis

 

  • Itis usually associated with viral inclusions, not the immunopathology seen in PV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pemphigus Vulgaris clinical presentation - Painful, recurrent oral lesions and histopathological evidence of suprabasal acantholysis with intercellular IgG and C3.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 50.7

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 499

Pemphigus Vulgaris (PV)

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with painful oral ulcers and flaccid bullae on her trunk. Physical examination shows that the bullae are easily ruptured, leaving denuded skin. A Tzanck smear from the base of a blister reveals acantholytic cells. Which condition does the patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pemphigus Vulgaris (PV)

 

Option B.

 

  • The presence of acantholytic cells on a Tzanck smear is indicative of PV, which is characterized by the loss of keratinocyte cell adhesion (acantholysis).

 

 

  • High power view of Tzanck cells in pemphigus vulgaris. Note the perinuclear halo visible in the marked cell.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bullous Pemphigoid –

 

  • Incorrect, as Tzanck smear is typically negative for acantholytic cells.

 

Option C. Erythema Multiforme –

 

  • Incorrect, usually presents with target lesions.

 

Option D. Dermatitis Herpetiformis–

 

  • Incorrect, as Tzanck smear is typically negative for acantholytic cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pemphigus Vulgaris by the presence of acantholytic cells on Tzanck smear.

 

Ref: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 503

 

Online Resources: https://ijdvl.com/acantholysis-revisited-back-to-basics/

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with flaccid vesicles over the trunk and oral mucosa with painful erosions. On examination, both the bulla spread sign and Nikolsky sign are positive. What will be the direct immunofluorescence findings of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fishnet IgG Deposition in the Epidermis

 

Option B.

 

  • Pemphigus vulgaris is the diagnosis from the clues given in the clinical vignette.
  • Direct immunofluorescence (DIF) in pemphigus vulgaris typically shows intercellular deposits of IgG and C3 throughout the epidermis, creating a "fishnet" pattern as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • This is consistent with the clinical presentation of flaccid vesicles and positive Nikolsky sign, which are characteristic of pemphigus vulgaris.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fishnet IgM deposition in the epidermis –

 

  • Incorrect, IgM is not typically involved in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Option C. Linear IgG deposition in dermo epidermal junction –

 

  • Incorrect, this is indicative of bullous pemphigoid.

 

Option D. Fishnet IgG deposition in the dermis –

 

  • Incorrect, in pemphigus vulgaris, IgG deposition is intercellular within the epidermis, not the dermis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pemphigus vulgaris using DIF, shows intercellular IgG and C3 deposition in the epidermis.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 50.3

choices.text: Acantholytic Cells
Clue Cells
Nikolsky Cells
Auspitz Cells

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presents with remitting & relapsing course of mucocutaneous lesions since last 8 years. On examination there are erosions in oral cavity and flaccid bullae over trunk. Which of the following cells are expected in the biopsy of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acantholytic Cells

 

Option A.

 

  • Acantholytic cells are characteristic of pemphigus vulgaris, which presents with mucocutaneous lesions, oral erosions, and flaccid bullae.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Clue cells

 

  • Clue cells are associated with bacterial vaginosis, not skin lesions.

 

Option C. Nikolsky cells

 

  • They are not a type of cell; the Nikolsky sign is a clinical feature where the skin sloughs off with pressure.

 

Option D. Auspitz cells

 

  • They are not a cell type; the Auspitz sign refers to pinpoint bleeding when scales are scraped away in psoriasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acantholytic cells in the biopsy of a patient with pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 50.7

choices.text: Bullous Pemphigoid
Herpes Zoster
Hailey Hailey Disease
Pemphigus Vulgaris

questions.text: A 31-year-old male presented with vesiculobullous lesions over the body. The Tzanck smear revealed the presence of acantholytic cells. The resident on duty ordered Direct ImmunoFluorescence which came out to be positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pemphigus Vulgaris

 

Option D.

 

  • It is identified by acantholytic cells on Tzanck smear and positive direct immunofluorescence which typically shows intercellular deposits of IgG and C3 in the epidermis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bullous Pemphigoid –

 

  • It can show linear IgG and C3 deposits at the basement membrane, but we cannot appreciate acantholytic cells in this condition as it is a subepidermal blistering disorder.

 

Option B. Herpes zoster –

 

  • This would typically show multinucleated giant cells (MNGCs) and acantholytic cells, but Direct ImmunoFluorescence would be negative in this condition.

 

 

  •  Tzanck smear showing secondary acantholysis in Herpes zoster. The yellow arrow points to a single acantholytic cell; the red arrow indicates a MNGC.

 

Option C. Hailey Hailey Disease –

 

  • This is a Genetic disorder in which we can see acantholytic cells, but Direct ImmunoFluorescence would be negative as there are no Autoantibodies in this condition.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Diagnose Pemphigus vulgaris with the presence of acantholytic cells on Tzanck smear and intercellular IgG and C3 deposition on direct immunofluorescence.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 50.3

 

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 495

choices.text: Cluster of Jewels
Chicken Wire
Fishnet
Row of Tombstone

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with erosions in the oral cavity & flaccid blisters and ulcers over the face, trunk & lower limbs. The Tzanck smear revealed the presence of acantholytic cells. Which of the following appearances is expected in the biopsy of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Row of Tombstone

 

Option D.

 

  • The clinical features and Tzanck smear findings are suggestive of a diagnosis of Pemphigus vulgaris.
  • Row of Tombstone appearance in the biopsy refers to the characteristic histological feature of pemphigus vulgaris, where the basal layer of keratinocytes remains attached to the basement membrane, resembling a row of tombstones, while the suprabasal keratinocytes lose adhesion, leading to intraepidermal blister formation.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cluster of jewels

 

  • This is seen in Linear IgA disease as vesicles are present in annular pattern mostly over face & buttocks.

 

 

Option B. Chicken wire

 

  • It typically refers to the pattern of deposition of immune reactants seen in direct immunofluorescence in pemphigus.

 

Option C. Fishnet

 

  • This refers to the pattern of IgG deposition seen in direct immunofluorescence in pemphigus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • "ROW OF TOMBSTONE" is a histological descriptor of pemphigus vulgaris indicating a suprabasal acantholytic blister on skin biopsy.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 50.7

 

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 503

choices.text: Pemphigus Vegetans
Pemphigus Vulgaris
Pemphigus Foliaceus
Erythema Multiforme

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 35-year-old patient who has presented with easily rupturing Flaccid Bulla on the Skin and whose Biopsy indicates a Suprabasal Split?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pemphigus Vulgaris

 

Option B.

 

  • Based on the clinical presentation of bullous lesions and the histologic finding of a suprabasal blister, Pemphigus vulgaris is suspected.
  • This condition involves the production of antibodies, particularly against Desmoglein 3, and sometimes Desmoglein 1. These antibodies are typically of the IgG type. Desmoglein 3 is primarily found in the basal and suprabasal layers of the skin and mucosa.
  • As a result, patients exhibit flaccid bullae on the skin, and mucosal involvement, especially in the oral mucosa, is common.

 

 

  • Ulceration may also occur in other areas such as the conjunctiva, nasopharynx, and larynx. Cutaneous lesions are more frequently observed on the scalp, face, neck, upper chest, and back.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pemphigus Vegetans:

 

  • Description: Pemphigus vegetans is a variant of pemphigus vulgaris. It features vesicles and bullae that evolve into verrucous (wart-like) lesions, particularly in skin folds.

 

 

  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: The primary presentation in the question doesn't describe verrucous or wart-like lesions.

 

Option C. Pemphigus foliaceus:

 

  • Description: Pemphigus foliaceus is another type of pemphigus but is characterized by more superficial skin blisters than pemphigus vulgaris, and it doesn't typically involve the mucous membranes.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: The biopsy of pemphigus foliaceus would show a split in the upper epidermis (subcorneal), not a suprabasal split.

 

Option D. Erythema multiforme:

 

  • Description: Erythema multiforme is an acute, immune-mediated skin condition. It is characterized by target-like lesions and is often triggered by infections (e.g., herpes simplex virus) or certain medications.

 

 

  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: The presentation of erythema multiforme is quite distinct with its target-like lesions, and a biopsy would not reveal a suprabasal split.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pemphigus vulgaris diagnosed by the presence of flaccid bullae that rupture easily and a suprabasal split on biopsy, indicating an autoimmune process causing loss of epidermal cell adhesion.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Page No 47.1-47.5, 50.1-50.10

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17619399/

Diabetes Mellitus

Lupus Vulgaris

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of Vesiculo Bullous lesions for the past 14 days. Which of the following diseases is least likely to present with fluid-filled lesions as seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lupus Vulgaris.

 

Option D.

 

  • Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis, which manifests with the skin lesion as described below, but NOT as fluid-filled vesicles or bullae.
  • Lupus vulgaris presents as single or few erythematous / violaceousannular plaques with central scarring and extending centrifugally.

 

 

  • Periphery shows erythematous deep-seated nodules which on diascopy may stand out as Apple jelly nodules.
  • They are most commonly seen in buttocks, upper extremities, and face.
  • Center is depigmented with paper-thin scar.
  • Papules may recur on the scarred areas, which enlarge and coalesce. This leads to the formation of large, firm, elevated plaques.

 

Skin conditions other than Vesiculo Bullous disorders which can present with Vesicles and Bullous lesions:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Impetigo –

 

  • It commonly presents with fluid-filled lesions that can develop into pustules.

 

Option B. Diabetes mellitus –

 

  • Bullosis Diabeticorum is characterized by a sudden and spontaneous appearance of vesicles and bullae within normal-appearing, non-inflamed skin of the distal extremities of diabetics.
  • The most frequent site is the feet

 

 

Option C. Porphyria –

 

  • Some types, like porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT), can present with fluid-filled blisters on sun-exposed areas.

 

 

  • Flaccid hemorrhagic bulla and tense vesicle with clear fluid on the forefinger, accompanied by crusts and scars in a patient of PCT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lupus vulgaris is a disease unlikely to present with vesiculobullous lesions compared to impetigo, diabetes-related skin conditions, and porphyria.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 27 Page No 27.21 27.22

 

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 555, 775, 1306

choices.text: Gram Staining of Blister Fluid
Culture and Sensitivity
Skin Biopsy and Direct Immuno Fluorescence
Tzanck Smear from the Floor of Bulla

questions.text: A 50-year-old male visits the clinic with complaints of recurrent episodes of oral ulcers, large areas of denuded skin & flaccid vesiculobullous eruptions. Nikolsky sign was found to be positive. Which of the following bedside studies is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tzanck Smear from the Floor of Bulla

 

Option D.

 

  • A Tzanck smear is a bedside cytological examination that can quickly reveal the presence of acantholytic cells, which are indicative of pemphigus, especially when combined with a positive Nikolsky sign.
  • The presence of acantholytic cells on a Tzanck smear is indicative of PV, which is characterized by the loss of keratinocyte cell adhesion (acantholysis).

 

 

  • High power view of Tzanck cells in pemphigus vulgaris. Note the perinuclear halo visible in the marked cell.

 

Some important findings on Tzanck smear are as follows:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Gram staining of blister fluid–

 

  • It is used for bacterial infections, not autoimmune vesiculobullous diseases.

 

Option B. Culture and sensitivity–

 

  • This is also used for identifying infections.

 

Option C. Skin biopsy and Direct Immunofluorescence–

 

  • Although this is the definitive test, it is not a bedside study and requires laboratory facilities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tzanck smear - rapidly detect acantholytic cells at the bedside in patients with suspected pemphigus.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 41.26

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the dermatology clinic with a sudden appearance of skin lesions on the entire upper half of the body for the past 7 days. On examination, you notice erythematous shallow erosions with blisters and yellowish scales over seborrheic areas, as shown in the image below. The oral mucosa is normal. Histology revealed a subcorneal cleft, and DIF shows IgG deposition in the granular layer of the epidermis and autoantibodies against Desmoglein 1. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pemphigus Foliaceus.

 

Option C.

 

  • It is characterized by shallow erosions, blisters, and crusts, especially in seborrheic areas, and is associated with autoantibodies against Desmoglein 1.

Image of predominant Scaling and crusting seen in Pemphigus foliaceous patients.

 

. The subcorneal cleft seen in histology and IgG deposition in the granular layer also supports this diagnosis.

Dermatological Conditions presenting in Seborrheic areas:

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bullous Pemphigoid

 

  • Typically involves deeper blisters and autoantibodies target the basement membrane, not Desmoglein.

 

Option B. Pemphigus Vulgaris –

 

  • Would generally involve the oral mucosa and shows antibodies against Desmoglein 3 > 1.

 

Option D. Dermatitis Herpetiformis –

 

  • Associated with gluten sensitivity and IgA deposition, NOT IgG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Diagnose Pemphigus foliaceus by the presence of blisters and erosions in seborrheic areas and autoantibodies against Desmoglein 1 with subcorneal clefts on histology.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 50.5

 

IADVL Textbook of Dermatology 2nd Edition Page No 860

 

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page no 500

choices.text: Auspitz Sign
Buschke Ollendroff Sign
Nikolsky Sign
Row of Tombstone Sign

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the Dermatology OPD with Complaints of Vesiculobullous lesions which are flaccid all over body with mucosal erosions & ulcers. The Senior resident in Dermatology department in which you are posted, does this clinical sign to look for the findings as shown in the image below. What is the name of this Clinical sign being elicited?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nikolsky Sign.

 

Option C.

 

  • Nikolsky sign: The sign is demonstrated when lateral pressure is applied on the border of an intact blister, which results in the dislodgment of the normal epidermis and extension of the blister.

 

 

  • The Nikolsky sign is a clinical diagnostic indicator where slight rubbing of the skin results in exfoliation of the outermost layer.
  • It is typically positive in conditions like pemphigus vulgaris.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Auspitz Sign

 

  • This sign is associated with Psoriasis and involves pinpoint bleeding when scales are scraped away.

 

Option B. Buschke Ollendroff Sign –

 

  • Ollendorff probe sign or Buschke-Ollendorff sign refers to the deep dermal tenderness elicited by pressing the Papular lesions of secondary syphilis with a pinhead, when the patient winces with pain.

 

Option D. Row of Tombstone Appearance

 

  • This refers to the histological appearance of basal cell layer keratinocytes in pemphigus vulgaris, not a clinical sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Utilize the Nikolsky sign to aid in the clinical diagnosis of diseases with flaccid vesiculobullous lesions such as pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 50.3

 

Online resources:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3884922/

choices.text: Spongiosis
Acanthosis
Acantholysis
Hyperkeratosis

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with recurrent flaccid bullae on an erythematous base on his face and trunk. He had similar lesions in the oral cavity, which are painful. The histopathology of the lesion is shown in the image below. What is the underlying mechanism responsible for the clinical features and histopathological changes in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acantholysis.

 

Option C.

 

  • The image provided is characteristic of pemphigus vulgaris, which is known for its "row of tombstone" appearance histologically.
  • This appearance is due to acantholysis, the process where keratinocytes lose their cohesion, leading to blister formation.

 

 

  • Direct Immunofluorescence would show intercellular deposits of IgG and C3 throughout the epidermis.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Spongiosis

 

  • It refers to intercellular edema in the epidermis, seen in conditions like eczema.

 

Option B. Acanthosis

 

  • It is characterized by thickening of stratum spinosum, not blister formation.

 

Option D. Hyperkeratosis

 

  • This is a thickening of the stratum corneum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize acantholysis as the pathomechanism in pemphigus vulgaris, which presents with flaccid bullae and "row of tombstone" appearance histologically

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 50.7

 

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 499

 

IADVL Textbook of Dermatology 2nd Edition Page No 860-861

choices.text: Statement 1 is False and Statement 2 is True
Statement 1 is True and Statement 2 is False
Both the statements are True but 2 is not explaining 1
Both the statements are True and 2 is explaining 1

questions.text:
Statement 1: Clinically a patient having flaccid bullae with painful erosions, will show Suprabasal split and inflammatory infiltrate in the blister cleft on histopathological examination.

 

Statement 2: Row of tombstones appearance is diagnostic of Pemphigus vulgaris
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both the Statements are True but 2 is not explaining 1

 

Option C.

 

  • Both statements are true about Pemphigus vulgaris but statement 2 is not explaining Statement 1

 

Statement 1

 

  • This describes the histopathological findings associated with pemphigus vulgaris, which indeed presents with flaccid bullae and painful erosions. The characteristic finding on histopathological examination is a suprabasal split with acantholysis, leading to the formation of intraepidermal bullae. There is also an inflammatory infiltrate in the blister cleft.

 

Statement 2

 

  • This correctly identifies the "row of tombstones" appearance as diagnostic of pemphigus vulgaris. This appearance is due to the basal layer of keratinocytes remaining attached to the basement membrane when the rest of the epidermal cells float away due to acantholysis, creating a visual similar to tombstones.

 

While both statements are true, statement 2 is not a direct conclusion of statement 1.

 

  • The "row of tombstones" is a description of the histopathological appearance, while statement 1 is about the clinical presentation and the general histopathological findings.

  • NOTE: Pemphigus foliaceous has a subcorneal split, hence Row of Tombstone appearance is NOT SEEN in this condition.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.

 

  • Incorrect because both statements are true.

 

Option B.

 

  • Incorrect because both statements are true.

 

Option D.

 

  • Incorrect because statement 2 is not explaining statement 1, even though both statements are true individually.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In pemphigus vulgaris, patients clinically present with flaccid bullae and painful erosions, and histologically show suprabasal acantholysis, which on the skin biopsy appears as a "row of tombstones."

  • NOTE: Pemphigus foliaceous has a subcorneal split, hence Row of Tombstone appearance is NOT SEEN in this condition.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page No. 50.1-50.7

choices.text: Psoriasis Vulgaris
Leishmaniasis
Mycosis Fungoides
Pemphigus Vulgaris

questions.text: The histopathology picture below is suggestive of?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pemphigus Vulgaris

 

Option D:

 

  • The given slide shows a row of tombstones' appearance, which is classically seen in Pemphigus vulgaris.
  • The production of antibodies, specifically those against Desmoglein 3, is seen in Pemphigus vulgaris. Desmoglein 1 antibodies are also occasionally associated. Usually, the antibodies are IgG antibodies.
  • The skin and mucosa's basal and suprabasal layers contain the majority of Desmoglein 3. Hemidesmosomes help in connecting basal layer to underlying dermo-epidermal junction, in pemphigus vulgaris there are no antibodies against Hemidesmosomes, so the basal layer remains attached to the underlying dermo-epidermal junction giving the classical Row of tombstones appearance.
  • The patients, therefore, present with flaccid bullae over the skin and due to Desmoglein 3 involvement, mucosal involvement can also be seen.
  • Oral mucosa is commonly affected.
  • Other areas where ulceration can be seen are conjunctiva, nasopharynx, larynx, etc.
  • Cutaneous lesions are more common over the scalp, face, neck, upper chest, and back.

 

Biopsy:

 

  • The basal layer remains adherent to the basement membrane and gives the resemblance to a row of tombstones.

 

 

IMAGE of row of tombstones appearance.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Psoriasis vulgaris:

 

  • This is an autoimmune disease characterized by hyperproliferation of keratinocytes leading to thickened, scaly plaques.
  • Histologically, it shows parakeratosis (retention of nuclei in the stratum corneum), elongation of rete ridges, and a neutrophilic infiltrate (Munro's microabscesses) as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • The tombstone appearance is not a feature of psoriasis.

 

Option B. Leishmaniasis:

 

  • It's a parasitic infection caused by the Leishmania species.
  • Histologically, it is characterized by macrophages containing the parasite (Leishman-Donovan bodies) in the dermis as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • The tombstone appearance is not seen in leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Mycosis fungoides:

 

  • This is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma.
  • Histologically, there is an atypical lymphocytic infiltrate in the epidermis (epidermotropism), and the formation of Pautrier's microabscesses (collections of lymphocytes in the epidermis) as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • It does not exhibit a tombstone appearance.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pemphigus vulgaris is characterized by intraepidermal blistering due to acantholysis, or separation of keratinocytes, as a result of autoantibody attack on desmosomal proteins.

 

Ref:  Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 50 Page No 50.1-50.8
